channel.title: Slightly Confused
channel.description: I have been looking for a new External HDD on ebay, and alas, my family keeps telling me I don't need one. The goal i am trying to achieve is make my computer, for lack of a better work, "faster". I have noticed the fuller and fuller the little 60GB HDD has gotten, it seems to have slower response on some things. Would putting everything possible on an external hard-drive speed it up back to its old state? I believe so, but some of my family thinks otherwise.

item.title: Slightly Confused
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

Performance does degrade on NTFS as space runs out, but it is unlikely to be that noticable, it’ll be a combination of a slow hard drive, fragmentation and NTFS being shit.

Read full topic

item.title: Slightly Confused
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

guys, hes actaully right, ntfs has known issues with perfomance degrading as space runs out (and its more like 20% remaining iirc rather than “a few hundred mb”)

people building arrays and shit based on ntfs plan for the drives to never fill

disks are also faster on the outside of the platter, but presumably he isnt taking advantage o this:p

hes still a tard

Read full topic

item.title: Slightly Confused
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

What he said here:

1. windows likes to get slow over time for no reason, so if you have had windows on for a year or more, a reformat would give you the biggest speed difference you'll see. 2. as lawl said, if you are down to a few gigs or HDD space on your OS drive, things will become a little slower, the page file will be come smaller and superfetch will become disabled 3. if any of the above, go buy that external HDD, transfer everything you want on there, reformat your internal drive, install windows on it 4. ??? 5. profit

And, this

Unhandled:

On the contrary, you’re just a moron who thinks hard drive capacity has something to do with computer speed.

Throw 2 different things. Also, gtfo dude, your seriously making yourself look like a prick.

Read full topic

I never said anything about HDD capacity. I was asking if MOVING my files onto an EXTERNAL hdd, would bring back the speed it had lost because of the files. Simple as that.

And, ever since I did that, the PC has almost back to its original state.

item.title: Slightly Confused
item.dc:creator: @Hyjall Hyjall
item.description:
@Hyjall wrote:

[quote=“Unhandled, post:3, topic:349721”][quote author=la­wl link=topic=446095.msg3274067#msg3274067 date=1279424382]
If you get really close to filling up your hdd it will get extremely fucking slow. But only when theres a few mb left. I forgot why
[/quote]
page file or something?

um no buying another hard drive won’t make it faster.
upgrade ram, reinstall windows, but dont expect a new drive to speed it up much.[/quote]

Correct, windows’ (using windows here because it’s the most common one) page file backup system flushes chunks of memory (pages) to the hard drive to conserve the space in the (about 1000 times faster) physical memory. This is to ensure no memory is wasted. You’ll only notice a performance drop if you’re REALLY low on space though.

Read full topic
